threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
How should I fix my lines and shading?
Want to add color but feel I need to nail shadows first.
Any critique helps

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6397666
What are you trying to learn? If you want to improve at drawing from a model or photo like this, you should look at the Bargue drawing course. Some general advice: You need to go slow and be careful in your measurements. Work out the large shapes and proportions first, then move to the smaller details. Begin your drawing with mostly straight lines, and try to observe carefully the inflection points of the curves in your reference. Start with a single value for your entire shadow mass. Squint your eyes to determine what belongs to shadow and what belongs to light. Once you have essentially "posterized" the image into sharply defined light and dark shapes, then begin gradually feathering out the shadows into the light masses, and adding the slightly darker details within the light. In general, the tendency of beginners is to have too much variation in the shadow mass, and to overstate reflected light, which causes the drawing to lose its sense of weight and pictorial impact. It is better if the shadow is kept uniform, and most of the interest is within the light areas.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6397804

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6397811
There's a book with all the plates available, on Amazon etc. It's kind of expensive. You can probably find similar information in videos and elsewhere. This was the way beginners were taught to draw in the French academies, and the same approach is used in most of the ateliers today. You start by copying from these types of plates, then move on to drawing from actual casts of classical sculpture fragments, then on to living models, all using the same method.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
This thread is dedicated to master studies, where you copy artwork you admire as a form of study. They are the quickest way to improve and learn about any fundamental you are having problems with. If you need to work on your hands, copy hands from other artists, and if you're having trouble with rendering, make careful studies of paintings with lighting you admire. Studies can be quick or long. You can even copy anatomy books like Bridgman, Morpho, and Hogarth. The type of studies you want to do depend on your personal goals and the types of problems you are grappling with.

Artists of all levels are welcome. Critiques and redlines are encouraged.

>>6397746
Symbol drawing isn’t a bad thing. It saves time if you know your fundies. It sounds like you’re still in the ‘all or nothing’ phase of loomis constructionism, thinking that everything needs to be feeltheform and autistically measured.

Something you learn later on is that there’s a greater freedom in applying anything and everything across the spectrum of art in order to create things. The problem occurs when you ignore fundies and go straight for symbol-drawing stylization, but desu even some of that has more soul than someone drawing lifeless still life with flawless clean lines.

Drawing properly is necessary but it should be discarded the second you’re proficient in fundies. If it becomes a crutch, your work will look like sterile shit that no one cares about.

>I'm thinking of getting the Wacom One, should I buy it?
Fuck off retard. Ask a better question.

Recommended tablets:

>Intuos 3
Best screenless tablet. Look for one on Craigslist or Ebay.
>Intuos 4, 5 & Pro
Also good options. Will burn through your nibs.
>Samsung Galaxy Tab S6 Lite
Budget portable display tablet. Very solid drawing experience with Wacom EMR tech, but a small 10.4" display area.
>Used iPad Pro 2nd Gen 12.9"
Best option for a display tablet.
>Galaxy Tab S7+/S8+
Good premium alternative to an iPad Pro
>One by Wacom (not Wacom One)
Solid cheap option

Avoid:

>XP-Pen, Huion, Gaomon and every other Chinese brand
Poor build quality, lackluster pens, broken tilt, struggles to register light pressure, horrible customer support and the displays are not calibrated. All Chinese brands have the same problems. Check out the webm to understand how bad they are. Also watch out, Chinese companies shill HARD on /ic/; they do a lot of samefagging and frequently hurl personal insults.

>Microsoft Surface Pro
The N-Trig digitizer means you will always get wobbly lines.

>Lenovo
Bad drawing performance because they're not designed with art in mind.

>iPads (brand new) - Bad value
>iMacs and Macbooks - Never buy this garbage under any circumstance. It's a locked ecosystem with rubbish hardware you can't upgrade.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6396939

It depends on your ambition.

It has been a centuries long tradition among artists to study skeletons and cadavers. We don't really have to do that per se today, though I would recommend checking out a few dissection videos on youtube if you can stomach them - a bit more reality than some dude's pencils.

Anatomy shouldn't be the first thing you jump on, like the other guy said. When you start getting into figure drawing, make sure you learn a good system of whole-body proportions first.

You can get by quite a bit with using references as often as you can but many successful artists still study every bone and muscle from books and models - there's a huge power to it (and fun). It's also easier than ever, there are so many available resources today, books and articles, skull casts on Amazon, 3D models on sketchfab, you name it.

>do I gotta learn all that shit

The shapes of the skeleton and the muscles look extremely daunting at first, but there's a certain rhythm to everything that makes it all simpler once you learn it. All muscles work in conjunction and follow just a few key patterns. Plus, the body is symmetrical so you only need to know half of it.

You should also know where to place your priorities. The skull is really helpful to understand in detail - the ribcage and pelvis are hidden under layers and can be more simplified. The knee is useful to understand because it's very shallow, but the leg bones are hidden under layers and layers of fat and muscle. The same with muscles, arm muscles tend to be more defined than the stomach or the legs.

>>6390868
I don't think that's "bad" art. This discussion reminds me of Gunpei Yokoi, the engineer and game designer who created (among other things) the Game Boy for Nintendo. Yokoi's genius was in taking outdated hardware and using it in novel ways. He recognized early on that very simple, lo-fi graphics could be more endearing and relatable than ultra-realism, and used this understanding to great advantage.

>No matter how much CG approaches reality, it will never be able to overtake real visuals. There will always be an unsurpassable limit...
>Do these playworlds really need to be that photorealistic, I wonder? I actually consider it more of a minus if the graphics are too realistic. There’s a similar line of thinking in the entertainment world—using soft focus lenses when women are filmed, for instance. When that is done, each person can project their own conception of “beautiful” onto the woman being filmed, and everyone will see their own personal Venus.
>If things are too realistic, there’s no room for your imagination, and the reality of those faces you thought were beautiful will be revealed. Or to use another common expression, it’s actually more erotic when a woman leaves some skin covered. Even if a video game doesn’t have the power to display very complex graphics, I believe your imagination has the power to transform that perhaps-unrecognizable sprite called a “rocket” into an amazing, powerful, “real” rocket.
>Television has gone from black and white to color, and now that we’re seeing high-definition tv it’s almost too detailed. You get that problem I mentioned, of seeing wrinkles of beautiful faces. Since television is mainly a medium for information, I think it’s better for it to be more clear, but games don’t require that. I think the world of a game feels larger when you can use your own imagination.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6396222
Source for those quotes: https://shmuplations.com/yokoi/

Related to the above: Remember the old Tamagotchi "virtual pet" keychains? The creature was a few dozen pixels on an unlit, monochrome, dot matrix screen. In spite of these limitations (or because of them?), people felt an emotional connection with their imaginary pets.
If you draw two dots and a line, people will see a face and respond on a gut level. If you spend hours rendering a face from a photograph, people will likely see all the flaws and be put off by it, unless you're an absolute master.

>>6396194
No,just explaining the history behind all this. I had planned for a different kind of strip,but although I was capable of drawing the chunks of a panel in pencil while balancing the Bristol board on my lap,but I didn't have the time at my computer to use Photoshop to isolate the images,chopping away the extra white of a drawing and leaving it as a layer with clear transparency surrounding it. And that takes time that I no longer had. So,a story sprang up from a random drawing of a demon head in a bubble. This strip. Not meant for public consumption, but I liked how the head was coming along,so I decided to add another character, and thinking about how they would interact. What sort of character? A hybrid of two other characters, anthromorph races being normally incompatible for breeding.
"It doesn't stop them from trying ",to quote Cassandra. As the pen made images fade into view,I invented personality and reason for these things I create. I like to make single panel snapshots of "a story in progress",with enough visual cues to imply a whole plot from a single moment of the circumstance the characters find themselves in. I thought it as no more than that.

Then I did another.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
And I did about 180 altogether, with some one shot pictures like I've explained, I only took it seriously 30 issues in,which meant that I took more time on the art beyond the bare bones storyboard strips that are deciding on the placement of props and characters, and I had 30 of those for the newspaper sized strip format that I originally planned for. I am thinking about returning to it,investing in a scanner and good paper.

Listen. I know that the strips are flawed. But it conveys a story. You read the words and ALL of the words,damn it,and look at the pictures and a story unfolds. The story is worth filming. Feel like criticism? Look at the source material for the movie the Bad Guys.

Anyway, this thread was about Soul.
My first example had a touch of it,if you were familiar with the characters. But flaws and all,a few thousand visitors a month liked it enough to keep coming back.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: Would you look at it for longer than one second?
threads.com:
No matter how much skill you got, how many years, decades of experience, how long you spend drawing it, how many hours, days, weeks, how unique your designs are, how personal it is for you or even how generic and trendy you made it, people won't fucking look at it for longer than one second.
Neat. Swipe. Like. Click away. Bookmark. NEXT!
You would do the same.
Everyone is an artist and art is everywhere. Infinite supply makes the value of a single piece nearly worthless. People spend more time reading the text in the balloons than looking at the art in the comic. More time reading the tweet than looking at the image embedded in the tweet. Even the most successful professionals only get a tiny bit more attention per person per drawing than a teenager who picked up the pencil yesterday and posted a stick figure.
Anyone else feels the same way?
I used to draw lots for fun, but when I think if I posted something on the internet it wouldn't captivate a single person, drawing feels meaningless. What is the point? Upload this and it's just a waste of space in someone's servers. A waste of data and of time.
In thousands of illustrations I have seen only a handful made me stop and look for longer than one second. This is my goal now. I'll study them to figure out what they did different and maybe I'll realize something and be able to do the same. If I can make people stop clicking and pause just to stare what I drew, I'll know I've made it.
I guess this makes me an attention whore. Maybe sovl comes from drawing what you want and not from caring about what other people think. But then what if "what I want" is to make others feel the same way I was made feel those handful of times?

last_replies.com: hey OP I'll try to explain what's going on in the reference pic you posted. The main source of light is the sun, shining from the viewer's left. This source of light is warm-shifted. However, there is also a secondary light source coming from the reflected light that's bouncing down from the atmosphere. This light is weaker, so can only been seen from her non-illuminated side. This is called ambient light and is blue-shifted. I've tried to apply the same principle to your piece, except with the sun from the viewer's right.

Sci-fi gave you brain damage. But the truth is that AI is here, and it is far easier to make then colony on the Moon. Lawyers and Judges are getting replaced month after AI manages to replace book writers. Same goes for good chunk of scientific fields that mostly work with texts. AI can already understand logic and predict outcomes based on text, the main limitor is memory (reason why textbots forget stuff so easily and constantly change subjects). We have no idea what will happen and how effective it will be once it learns how to remember. Maybe just giving textbot human-like long term memory will immediately turn it into AGI, maybe it wont change anything and just allow it to generate fantasy novels. You cant really predict what will happen since AI research is advancing much much faster then neurology. After all, all it took for AI to master drawing was to make it recognize objects on a picture very well, when just strap it to noise generator and boom, you got machine that will draw you anything in any artstyle, as well as make any kind of fake photo and soon maybe even make 3D objects. Nobody knew it could replace artists this easily, so maybe giving it extra memory will make it finally understand topics described to it, and become AGI by just reading a lot.
Nobody knows.

If you are a /beg/inner or /int/ermediate in art, please use this thread to post pieces for critique or ask for advice.
Use this thread instead of making new threads or post in the drawthread with fundamental exercises.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:
1. screenshot the image and post that instead
2. change camera capture settings to something smaller
3. send to computer and resize in MSPaint

READ THE STICKY:
Completed: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uwaXKU7ev6Tw_or__o8ARpUb6r2rCZYJGqwSFV9AD98/edit

Old: http://www.squidoo.com/how-to-draw-learn

RECOMMENDED BOOKS FOR BEGINNERS:
Read the sticky

TRY TO BE ACTIVE AND GIVE PEOPLE SOME FEEDBACK.
When giving feedback, avoid vague "advice" - point what's wrong and try to give the anon you're quoting a clear direction to improve their art (study heads < watch THIS VIDEO about head structure, read THIS SECTION of THIS ARTIST'S BOOK, etc).

its a lot of lines, but they are done so fast and haphazardly that its pointless. even as an exercise, youve failed. circles are done fast and have tails or miss connecting. contour lines dont actually obey the shape they are contouring most of the time and vary from contour to contour. lines have littel to no lineweight differentiation outside extremes like large black lines. theres a lot of wobble on lines too. they dont feel smooth when you are doing longer lines or lots of lines in a row. the distance between lines in sequences is also arbitrary. you dont care or think about them at any point. just mindless lines haphazardly thrown. the distances matter. they can be uniform or imply perspective by gaps shrinking or expanding between them as you go and so on. line weights would further differentiate the lines and imply form and shape (thicker near edges/thinner in mid could show it bulging towards us, like say that eye looking thing at the top, and give it more form). many of the curved shapes just have no dimensionality. feel flat even with contours. the ones you put dots on are affected greatly because you refuse to have diversity in line weights. if the dots were larger and get thinner as it curves around and if the dots contoured as well it would go a long way. add some line weights to the conotours or exterior lines and it really pops. everything is just flattened into nothing with lazy, mindless lines.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Y'alls posting absolutely useless advice. You don't need high level rendering skills for OP's pic.

There's a standard formula for this type of image:
1. Draw base color. We'll paint light to dark, so do pale light pink for skin, mid orange for hair.
2. Take a flat brush and pick a darker shade of pink. Paint the shadows cel-style. Same for hair using a darker shade of orange.
3. Take the blur tool, run it thru the edges of the shadow.
4. Add finishing touches like highlights.etc.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6393877
Lasso and soft brush mainly. Put down your flats (make them your mid tone), then create a clipping mask layer ontop. Then paint in the ambient shadows with a soft brushsoft, (the general form shadows not the drop shadows). Then on the same layer with the same color lay down your drop shadows using the lasso. Might want to duplicate the ambient layer first for back up incase you screw up. To clean it up I would make another clipping layer ontop of the last one and paint over top sample from underneath. This is a really simple base to start from. The real trick to making great shadows is understanding the your darker skin tones and your shadows are NOT THE SAME. They overlap, so what you want to do is make the base I just explained your darker skin tones then ontop of all you did brush your true shadow color in selectively. The easiest way to find your shadow is to sample from your background. The warm skin cool shadow, cool skin warm shadow thing is more about creating good contrast between the subject and the background then actually making proper shadows. So, before you start dropping in shadows figure out your background. Shadows are also sponges for color so if you want to dial them up even more you can try putting different colors from around the painting in different areas, just don't get carried away or they won't gel right. After that it's high lights, bounce lights, and subsurface scattering. Oh, and I said Lasso and softbruch mainly but every painting is comes down to both soft and hard brush. It's doesn't matter which one you start with, it just matters that you know when to soften and when to harden. The Lasso is just best for making perfect gradients that even the best soft brush technique can't produce as quickly. Ok, that's it from me, cheers.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6393182
If you just want to draw a copy, use a method similar to the Bargue drawing course. This is the method taught in the French-style ateliers. See picrel.
Left image: Find the vertical and horizontal center lines. Notice the horizontal line touches the top of the lips, while the vertical line locates the inner corner of her left eye (right eye in the picture). You can further subdivide the picture to find additional points. The usual analog method is to hold the pencil at arm's length, with the tip at one point and your thumb on the pencil marking the other point. Then move the pencil to check if the distances are equal.
Center image: To keep your copy in proper alignment, use plumb (vertical) and horizontal lines to find points that line up. In the atelier, the student would hold out his hand with a weighted string attached to give the vertical line, and use the pencil or straight edge for the horizontal. Be careful, check twice and don't rush.
Third image: Begin the drawing by lightly sketching in large, "enveloping" forms using straight lines. Straight lines are easier to judge than curves. The subtlety of curvature can be added after the overall proportions are secured. You may also carry oblique lines beyond individual forms to further maintain proper alignment. Note how the line of the cheek continues to the vertex of the collar.
The overarching principle here is to work from the general to the specific. Find the large proportions, then go smaller and smaller. Treat the shadow areas as shapes, too. Refinement and subtlety come last.

>Info on this
Microwaving plasticine clay means it can get on the inside of the microwave and transfer into your food. It happens with monster clay too. If you're going to liquefy your monster clay in the microwave then ok but I suggest you have a seperate one for clay. I think the crock pot is the best even though it takes a while to melt your clay down. You can use higher heat to initially melt and then turn it low to keep it warm while you work. Anyways the not microwaving, it's the same reason you never fire clay or cure sculpey in an oven you cook food in.

And for smoothing you can put hot clay on to fill gaps and rake it while it's cooling or cooled entirely to soften the smudges out. You could use a heat gun or a culinary butane torch if you want to smooth it thay way, just be careful with the torch, flame doesnt need to touch the clay, you just need to heat near it to soften, it works better than a lighter.

threads.com:
I am currently in the process in designing a fantasy world. I started yesterday on laying out the map. While I found a lot of good guides online, they mainly focus on the very abstract, high-level stuff like mountain ranges, great rivers, barrier forrests and capital cities. This is all good, and helped me create my continent map, but I want to go down to the local, regional level.

Currently, the regions are all basically plain white spaces, with occasional great river cutting across. I KNOW that in reality, this would be full of local streams, small rivers, hundreds of lakes, hamlets, roads, hills etc. But I don't really know how to start placing them all. I guess I start with an enchanced view of a region, taking a new A4 page and drawing its borders in it, but then what? I have zero clue how streams or rivers occur naturally. How swamps occur. Where would villages form (and no, I know from real life they don't all form next to a river).

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6392528
You don't just manifest these worlds in your mind and use astral projection to be amongst your creation and authenticly flesh out your concepts?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6392528
What is the purpose of this world that makes you want that level of details? If this is for a game campaign or a story then I suggest writing the story first then the world later. The world is supposed to serve the story not the other way around. For example when a bandit the hero just defeated flees to a nearby location, you proceed to place a mountain or a forest there.
If it's just for fun then I guess you should first think about the elevations. Rivers flowed from high places to low places. Streams branched out from there etc. You seem to already understand the basic, but going beyond placing the landscape however you like seems kinda autistic. You can consult geographic books for that, but why? People who read/play your stuff won't have that level of knowledge anyway. And terrains irl vary enough that almost any combinations should be possible. Except for the ones that only occur in certain climates I suppose.

Also villages usually form around a food source, like a river, forest or good soil to grow crops. Except for unique reasons like for religious or strategic purposes.
